issues.title: Getting error aclling HttpHeaders on this line  HttpHeaders requestHeaders = new HttpHeaders()
Spring social twitter 1.1.0
issues.body:
Hi, would it be possible to update the twitter client example to use spring-social-twitter:1.1.0.RELEASE? I'm trying to update the version so I can use the 'getUnmodifiedText' method on Tweet, but I keep running in to dependency problems - it looks like the transitive dependencies for the latest version of spring-social-twitter are much more complex than they used to be, so I either end up with dex problems when spring-beans gets included, or if I fix that I get runtime exceptions for missing classes.

Thanks.

issues.title: STOMP over WebSockets API for Android equivalent to RestTemplate
issues.body:
Hello Mr. Clarckson,

First of all thank you very much for your invaluable contributions to the open source Spring/Android communities.

RestTemplate API for Android is extremely useful to develop client-server communications in the Android platform. It would be great to have an excellent guide as: http://spring.io/guides/gs/consuming-rest-android/ oriented to WebSockets technology (http://spring.io/guides/gs/messaging-stomp-websocket/) for Android. Does Spring Roadmap contemplates the development of an equivalent API for STOMP over WebSockets?

Thank you very much for your attention,

Warren de León Ofalla http://warrendeleon.com

issue_comments.body: Oops, sorry about that.  I committed something that wasn't intended to be committed.  The build is fixed now.  I've removed the offending bits.  I've also created a task to set up a CI build for this samples project to help catch this more quickly in the future.  https://jira.springsource.org/browse/ANDROID-53  Thanks for the feedback!
Yes, agreed. I'll update the dependency. Thanks for pointing that out!
Updated the samples to Spring for Android 1.0.0.RC1 and created a tag so you can always go to that snapshot.

Are you using Maven for dependency management? The packages you listed are part of Spring Social; spring-social-core, and two sub projects spring-social-facebook, and spring-social-twitter.

http://www.springsource.org/spring-social

Unfortunately, there are a few more you'll need. Here's the breakdown of the dependencies.

spring-android-rest-template
    |__ spring-android-core

spring-android-auth
    |__ spring-android-rest-template
    |__ spring-android-core
    |__ spring-security-crypto
    |__ spring-social-core

spring-social-twitter
    |__ spring-security-crypto
    |__ spring-social-core
    |__ jackson-mapper-asl

spring-social-facebook
    |__ spring-social-core
    |__ jackson-mapper-asl

jackson-mapper-asl
    |__ jackson-core-asl

Of course. No problem. Are you able to build the samples project now? Responding to this thread made me realize that I need to provide better documentation for this scenario in the Spring for Android docs. It's on my todo list now. If you are able to build the samples, let me know, and we can close this issue. Thanks.

http://static.springsource.org/spring-android/docs/1.0.x/reference/htmlsingle/

Understood. I appreciate the response, regardless. Do keep an eye on Spring for Android and Spring Social. We have some improvements planned around the connection process, to make it easier to set up and use. Thanks.
Updated dependencies in the sample apps, including spring social. Thanks!

Spring Social makes a network request to Facebook when it creates the connection. In the sample app, this method call was happening on the main UI thread. Newer versions of Android disallow network requests on the UI thread, so this call has been moved into an AsyncTask.
As a side note, I've also updated to targetSdkVersion 17, updated dependencies, and cleaned up most of the lint warnings. Thanks for reporting!

The Facebook session cookie was being saved in the webview. Now clearing all cookies when the activity resumes, so Facebook won't automatically reauthorize the app, forcing the user to login in again.
Thanks!
I've updated all the samples to use Android Maven Plugin 3.8.0. Thanks for reporting!

You don't actually have to register the `x-android-org-springsource-twitterclient://twitter-oauth-response` URL with the Twitter app settings. In fact, the callback URL configured on Twitter doesn't really matter in this case. The callback URL is sent to Twitter within the request to fetch the OAuth request token.

Note that within the `AndroidManifest.xml` we specify an `<intent-filter>` for the `TwitterWebOAuthActivity` which configures this callback URL. This filter tells Android to redirect requests to the activity.

``` xml
<activity
    android:name=".TwitterWebOAuthActivity"
    android:excludeFromRecents="true"
    android:noHistory="true" >
    <intent-filter>
        <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW" />

        <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
        <category android:name="android.intent.category.BROWSABLE" />

        <data
            android:host="twitter-oauth-response"
            android:scheme="x-org-springsource-android-twitterclient" />
    </intent-filter>
</activity>
```

Note also in `res/values/connect_settings.xml` the `twitter_oauth_callback_url` string is again configured. This string is used in `TwitterWebOAuthActivity` to fetch the Twitter request token. 

``` xml
<string name="twitter_oauth_callback_url">x-org-springsource-android-twitterclient://twitter-oauth-response</string>
```

``` java
@Override
protected OAuthToken doInBackground(Void... params) {
    // Fetch a one time use Request Token from Twitter
    return connectionFactory.getOAuthOperations().fetchRequestToken(getOAuthCallbackUrl(), null);
}
```

If you want to modify the callback URL for your own app, you need to make sure it is configured the same in the `AndroidManifest.xml` and `res/values/connect_settings.xml`.

Happy to help! Glad that worked! Note that I'm planning to add another sample that uses a native android view for signing into Twitter. The use of the web page redirect as illustrated in this sample is a little outdated now. Thanks for the interest in the project!

Facebook supports some different ways to authenticate and authorize your app. The method used in the sample makes use of a manual flow which is described in the following link. The callback URL you are asking about is required for that flow. For the future, this is an area where we need to improve the integration of spring social with Android.

https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login/manually-build-a-login-flow/

commits.message: moving cast to inside the method

added a destroyed check before dismissing the dialog. When the screen is switched (ctrl+F11 in the emulator), the activity is destroyed and a new one is created. The dialog therefor has a reference to an activity that is destroyed, and throws an exception when its dismiss() method is called
woops forgot a static final on one TAG member
Removing onListItemClick call to super, this method is a no-op in ListActivity
replacing TAG values, so that is uses class.getSimpleName() instead of string values. Doesn't cost much, and avoid renaming errors
Setting the TAG members to be static final : those are constants, no need for one ref per activity instance
Added .classpath, .project and .settings to git ignored files
